sentence: The major indexes ended last week on a strong note, but appear on track to make a soft start in today's session.

We don't have much on the data front this morning, but the rest of this week will bring a bunch of housing-related data and earnings results from big-box retailers like Wal-Mart ( WMT ), Target ( TGT ) and others.
Minutes of the last FOMC meeting and the April CPI are coming out this week as well.

On the housing front, the key report this week will be Tuesday's Housing Starts, which was disappointingly weak the last time around and came in below the one-million unit mark for a second month in a row.
The April reading coming out tomorrow is expected to cross that key level, but that will take it where we averaged for most of last year.
Starts have notably remained below the cycle's peak levels in the mid-2000's when they averaged around two million units on a seasonally adjusted annualized basis.
Demographics alone would call for a material ramp-up in construction activity, but the improvement has been slow to materialize.
Homebuilder sentiment held up better even as Starts came down earlier this year - the sentiment index coming out a little later today is expected to build on the strong showing last month.
The Q1 earnings reports from Home Depot ( HD ) and Lowe's ( LOW ) this week will give us some perspective on the health of the housing markets.
The ­­Retail sector's scorecard now shows that we have results from 25 retailers out of 41 total in the S&P 500 index.
Total earnings for these 25 retailers are up +6.5% on +10.9% higher revenues, with 84% beating earnings estimates and 52% coming ahead of revenue expectations.
This is better performance than we have seen from these 25 retailers in other recent periods.

Strong results from earlier Retail sectors in the restaurant and online spaces drove the sector's performance momentum, though results in recent days from department stores have been on the weak side.
It will be interesting to see how this week's big-box retail group will fare.

It has been a tough retail environment lately, with a combination of weather issues in the first quarter of the year and logistical challenges related to West Coast ports adding to longstanding competitive challenges.
We are seeing these factors getting cited to varying degrees in the department store results.
On top of these known issues is the uncertain consumer spending backdrop, with retailers' hopes of benefiting from low oil prices not coming to fruition.
